title: Creating a loop until user enters a specific value to exit program
author: t2_139ii36c
text:
Hello

The design of this project is to enter a number, and if the number is or is not a fibonacci number, the output will state "# is/is not a fibonacci number." The program is going to continuously ask user to enter a number until user inputs -1 from where the program will exit.

    import math
    def isPerfectSquare(x):
        s= int(math.sqrt(x))
        return s*s == x
    
    def isFibonacci(n):
        return isPerfectSquare(5*n*n +4) or isPerfectSquare(5*n*n - 4)
    
    def main():
        print("Fibonacci number identifier (enter -1 to quite)")
        i = int(input("Please enter a number: "))
    
        if i == -1:
            print("Goodbye :) !")
    
        elif (isFibonacci(i) == True):
            print (i, "is a fibonacci number")
    
        else:
            print(i, "is not a fibonacci number")
    

In this case, when I input a number it tells me I have/dont have a fibonacci number. It won't re ask for me to enter a number. When I enter -1, program says "goodbye!" and exits. 

How can I incorporate loops to ask user to keep asking for a number until this condition is met?

\[sample\]

    Enter a #: 5
    5 is a fibo number
    Enter a #: -1 
    Goodbye! :) 

I hope this makes sense. Appreciate any help.

comments.author: BestNameEverCR
comments.body:
You can ask for input, and then do a while loop, with a condition that you see fits. If you want separate print statements depending on input, do an if-statement inside the loop. 

    fib=int(input(“blah blah”))
    while fib not isfib or fib!= -1:
        print(“not a fib number”)
        print(“enter -1 to exit”)
        fib=int(input(“blah blah”))


On your comment, the main function is to keep the other functions of your script separate. When/if you import the program into another script you know you can run the whole program by calling main, or call individual functions. It’s more of an organizational thing IMO
